Response Generation and Direct Response Generation. Evaluation metrics
encompass both linguistic quality and task success rates, revealing surprising
insights into the necessity or redundancy of explicit intent modelling. Our
findings challenge conventional assumptions in conversational AI pipelines,
offering actionable guidelines for designing more efficient and effective
response generation systems.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates whether explicit intent recognition is necessary for generating high-quality service responses in conversational AI, comparing intent-based and direct response generation methods.
AI.motivation: To determine if intent recognition is an essential step for effective conversational AI responses, thereby influencing response generation system designs.
AI.method: A comparative study using two publicly available service interaction datasets to benchmark several state-of-the-art language models on Intent-First Response Generation vs. Direct Response Generation.
AI.result: Evaluation showed unexpected insights into the necessity of explicit intent modeling, challenging conventional assumptions in conversational AI and providing guidelines for more efficient response systems.
AI.conclusion: The study suggests that models can bypass explicit intent recognition without degrading the quality of service responses, leading to more streamlined conversational AI designs.
key_contributions: Comparative analysis of intent-based and direct response generation methods.
Actionable guidelines for improving response generation systems in conversational AI.
Insights that challenge existing assumptions regarding intent recognition in service responses.

title: Masked Diffusion Language Models with Frequency-Informed Training
summary:
We present a masked diffusion language modeling framework for data-efficient
training for the BabyLM 2025 Challenge. Our approach applies diffusion training
objectives to language modeling under strict data constraints, incorporating
frequency-informed masking that prioritizes learning from rare tokens while
maintaining theoretical validity. We explore multiple noise scheduling
strategies, including two-mode approaches, and investigate different noise
weighting schemes within the NELBO objective. We evaluate our method on the
BabyLM benchmark suite, measuring linguistic competence, world knowledge, and
human-likeness. Results show performance competitive to hybrid
autoregressive-masked baselines, demonstrating that diffusion-based training
offers a viable alternative for data-restricted language learning.

AI.tldr: A masked diffusion language modeling framework is proposed for efficient training under data constraints, focusing on learning from rare tokens and achieving competitive performance in language modeling.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of data-efficient training for language models, particularly under strict data constraints, while improving the learning from rare tokens.
AI.method: The framework incorporates diffusion training objectives and explores multiple noise scheduling strategies and weighting schemes within the NELBO objective.
AI.result: The proposed method demonstrates competitive performance on the BabyLM benchmark suite compared to hybrid autoregressive-masked baselines.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion-based training serves as a viable alternative for language learning in data-restricted scenarios, with an emphasis on linguistic competence and human-likeness.
key_contributions: Introduction of a masked diffusion language modeling framework
Frequency-informed masking for rare token learning
Evaluation on the BabyLM benchmark suite with competitive results

title: Entropy2Vec: Crosslingual Language Modeling Entropy as End-to-End Learnable Language Representations
summary:
We introduce Entropy2Vec, a novel framework for deriving cross-lingual
language representations by leveraging the entropy of monolingual language
models. Unlike traditional typological inventories that suffer from feature
sparsity and static snapshots, Entropy2Vec uses the inherent uncertainty in
language models to capture typological relationships between languages. By
training a language model on a single language, we hypothesize that the entropy
of its predictions reflects its structural similarity to other languages: Low
entropy indicates high similarity, while high entropy suggests greater
divergence. This approach yields dense, non-sparse language embeddings that are
adaptable to different timeframes and free from missing values. Empirical
evaluations demonstrate that Entropy2Vec embeddings align with established
typological categories and achieved competitive performance in downstream
multilingual NLP tasks, such as those addressed by the LinguAlchemy framework.

AI.tldr: Entropy2Vec is a novel framework for creating cross-lingual language embeddings using the entropy of monolingual language models.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of traditional typological inventories that are affected by feature sparsity and static snapshots, providing a more dynamic method for capturing language similarities.
AI.method: Entropy2Vec quantifies the structural similarity between languages by assessing the entropy of monolingual language model predictions, leading to dense embeddings that adapt to different contexts.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show that Entropy2Vec embeddings correspond with established typological categories and perform competitively in various multilingual NLP tasks, including those handled by the LinguAlchemy framework.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides a robust alternative to existing methods, offering embeddings that are both comprehensive and adaptable to different languages.
key_contributions: Introduction of a framework leveraging entropy for language representation
Development of dense, adaptable embeddings free from missing values
Demonstrated alignment with typological categories and competitive NLP task performance

title: ToM-SSI: Evaluating Theory of Mind in Situated Social Interactions
summary:
Most existing Theory of Mind (ToM) benchmarks for foundation models rely on
variations of the Sally-Anne test, offering only a very limited perspective on
ToM and neglecting the complexity of human social interactions. To address this
gap, we propose ToM-SSI: a new benchmark specifically designed to test ToM
capabilities in environments rich with social interactions and spatial
dynamics. While current ToM benchmarks are limited to text-only or dyadic
interactions, ToM-SSI is multimodal and includes group interactions of up to
four agents that communicate and move in situated environments. This unique
design allows us to study, for the first time, mixed cooperative-obstructive
settings and reasoning about multiple agents' mental state in parallel, thus
capturing a wider range of social cognition than existing benchmarks. Our
evaluations reveal that the current models' performance is still severely
limited, especially in these new tasks, highlighting critical gaps for future
research.

AI.tldr: Introduction of ToM-SSI, a multimodal benchmark for testing Theory of Mind in complex social interactions.
AI.motivation: To provide a more comprehensive evaluation of Theory of Mind capabilities beyond traditional benchmarks that only assess basic interactions.
AI.method: Developed a new benchmark (ToM-SSI) that involves group interactions and spatial dynamics in multimodal settings, allowing assessment of mixed cooperative and obstructive behaviors.
AI.result: Current models show limited performance in these complex tasks, revealing significant gaps in their Theory of Mind understanding.
AI.conclusion: The ToM-SSI benchmark opens avenues for more nuanced research in social cognition and highlights the need for improved models in handling complex interactions.
key_contributions: Introduced ToM-SSI benchmark for dynamic social interactions.
Demonstrated the inadequacy of existing models in complex Theory of Mind tasks.
Facilitated the study of mixed cooperative and obstructive settings in multi-agent scenarios.
AI.limitations: The benchmark may not encompass all nuances of human social interactions and relies on the design of the test environment.

title: ICR: Iterative Clarification and Rewriting for Conversational Search
summary:
Most previous work on Conversational Query Rewriting employs an end-to-end
rewriting paradigm. However, this approach is hindered by the issue of multiple
fuzzy expressions within the query, which complicates the simultaneous
identification and rewriting of multiple positions. To address this issue, we
propose a novel framework ICR (Iterative Clarification and Rewriting), an
iterative rewriting scheme that pivots on clarification questions. Within this
framework, the model alternates between generating clarification questions and
rewritten queries. The experimental results show that our ICR can continuously
improve retrieval performance in the clarification-rewriting iterative process,
thereby achieving state-of-the-art performance on two popular datasets.

AI.tldr: The paper presents ICR, a novel iterative framework for Conversational Query Rewriting that enhances understanding through clarification questions and improves retrieval performance.
AI.motivation: To overcome challenges in end-to-end rewriting approaches due to multiple fuzzy expressions, facilitating better query identification and rewriting.
AI.method: The ICR framework alternates between generating clarification questions and reformulating queries iteratively.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate that ICR outperforms existing methods, achieving state-of-the-art results on two major datasets.
AI.conclusion: The iterative communication between clarification and rewriting leads to improved query understanding and information retrieval.
key_contributions: Introduction of the ICR framework for Conversational Query Rewriting.
Demonstration of iterative improvement in query understanding and retrieval performance.
Establishment of state-of-the-art results on benchmark datasets.

title: PRIM: Towards Practical In-Image Multilingual Machine Translation
summary:
In-Image Machine Translation (IIMT) aims to translate images containing texts
from one language to another. Current research of end-to-end IIMT mainly
conducts on synthetic data, with simple background, single font, fixed text
position, and bilingual translation, which can not fully reflect real world,
causing a significant gap between the research and practical conditions. To
facilitate research of IIMT in real-world scenarios, we explore Practical
In-Image Multilingual Machine Translation (IIMMT). In order to convince the
lack of publicly available data, we annotate the PRIM dataset, which contains
real-world captured one-line text images with complex background, various
fonts, diverse text positions, and supports multilingual translation
directions. We propose an end-to-end model VisTrans to handle the challenge of
practical conditions in PRIM, which processes visual text and background
information in the image separately, ensuring the capability of multilingual
translation while improving the visual quality. Experimental results indicate
the VisTrans achieves a better translation quality and visual effect compared
to other models. The code and dataset are available at:
https://github.com/BITHLP/PRIM.

AI.tldr: This paper presents Practical In-Image Multilingual Machine Translation (IIMMT) by introducing the PRIM dataset and a new model called VisTrans.
AI.motivation: Current IIMT research relies on synthetic data, which does not adequately represent real-world conditions. This gap necessitates a focus on practical multilingual machine translation using images.
AI.method: The authors annotate a dataset called PRIM, consisting of real-world images with complex backgrounds and diverse text, and propose an end-to-end model, VisTrans, which processes visual information separately from text.
AI.result: VisTrans outperforms existing models in terms of both translation quality and visual effectiveness across a range of multilingual scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The PRIM dataset and VisTrans model contribute towards bridging the gap between synthetic and real-world IIMT, enabling better applicability in multilingual translation tasks.
key_contributions: Introduction of the PRIM dataset for real-world IIMT
Development of the VisTrans model for improved translation and visual quality
Demonstrated effectiveness of the model on complex image data.

title: Triadic Fusion of Cognitive, Functional, and Causal Dimensions for Explainable LLMs: The TAXAL Framework
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly being deployed in high-risk
domains where opacity, bias, and instability undermine trust and
accountability. Traditional explainability methods, focused on surface outputs,
do not capture the reasoning pathways, planning logic, and systemic impacts of
agentic LLMs.
  We introduce TAXAL (Triadic Alignment for eXplainability in Agentic LLMs), a
triadic fusion framework that unites three complementary dimensions: cognitive
(user understanding), functional (practical utility), and causal (faithful
reasoning). TAXAL provides a unified, role-sensitive foundation for designing,
evaluating, and deploying explanations in diverse sociotechnical settings.
  Our analysis synthesizes existing methods, ranging from post-hoc attribution
and dialogic interfaces to explanation-aware prompting, and situates them
within the TAXAL triadic fusion model. We further demonstrate its applicability
through case studies in law, education, healthcare, and public services,
showing how explanation strategies adapt to institutional constraints and
stakeholder roles.
  By combining conceptual clarity with design patterns and deployment pathways,
TAXAL advances explainability as a technical and sociotechnical practice,
supporting trustworthy and context-sensitive LLM applications in the era of
agentic AI.

AI.tldr: Introducing TAXAL, a triadic alignment framework for enhancing explainability in agentic LLMs by integrating cognitive, functional, and causal dimensions.
AI.motivation: To address the trust and accountability issues associated with large language models deployed in high-risk domains due to opacity, bias, and instability.
AI.method: A triadic fusion framework named TAXAL that combines cognitive, functional, and causal dimensions for explainability, supported by synthesis of existing methods and case studies.
AI.result: Demonstrated the applicability of TAXAL through case studies in various fields, showing its effectiveness in adapting explanation strategies to different sociotechnical contexts.
AI.conclusion: TAXAL enhances explainability as both a technical and sociotechnical practice, facilitating trustworthy LLM applications.
key_contributions: Introduction of the TAXAL framework for LLM explainability
Synthesis of existing explanation methods within the TAXAL model
Case studies demonstrating the framework's applicability across various fields.

title: Hunyuan-MT Technical Report
summary:
In this report, we introduce Hunyuan-MT-7B, our first open-source
multilingual translation model, which supports bidirectional translation across
33 major languages and places a special emphasis on translation between
Mandarin and several ethnic minority languages as well as dialects.
Furthermore, to serve and address diverse translation scenarios and enhance
model performance at test time, we introduce Hunyuan-MT-Chimera-7B, a
translation model inspired by the slow thinking mode. This model integrates
multiple outputs generated by the Hunyuan-MT-7B model under varying parameter
settings, thereby achieving performance superior to that of conventional
slow-thinking models based on Chain-of-Thought (CoT). The development of our
models follows a holistic training process specifically engineered for
multilingual translation, which begins with general and MT-oriented
pre-training to build foundational capabilities, proceeds to Supervised
Fine-Tuning (SFT) for task-specific adaptation, and culminates in advanced
alignment through Reinforcement Learning (RL) and weak-to-strong RL. Through
comprehensive experimentation, we demonstrate that both Hunyuan-MT-7B and
Hunyuan-MT-Chimera-7B significantly outperform all translation-specific models
of comparable parameter size and most of the SOTA large models, particularly on
the task of translation between Mandarin and minority languages as well as
dialects. In the WMT2025 shared task (General Machine Translation), our models
demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, ranking first in 30 out of 31
language pairs. This result highlights the robustness of our models across a
diverse linguistic spectrum, encompassing high-resource languages such as
Chinese, English, and Japanese, as well as low-resource languages including
Czech, Marathi, Estonian, and Icelandic.

AI.tldr: Hunyuan-MT-7B is a bidirectional multilingual translation model, excelling in 33 languages, particularly Mandarin and minority languages. Hunyuan-MT-Chimera-7B improves performance with multiple outputs. Both models show state-of-the-art results in translation tasks, especially at WMT2025.
AI.motivation: To enhance multilingual translation, especially for underrepresented languages and dialects, and to improve model performance in diverse translation scenarios.
AI.method: The models follow a holistic training process: starting with general and MT-oriented pre-training, proceeding to Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) for specific tasks, and culminating in advanced alignment techniques using Reinforcement Learning.
AI.result: Both models significantly outperform other translation-specific models and several leading large models, achieving first place in 30 out of 31 language pairs at WMT2025.
AI.conclusion: Hunyuan-MT-7B and Chimera-7B demonstrate superior translation capabilities across a wide range of languages, highlighting their applicability in multilingual settings.
key_contributions: Introduction of Hunyuan-MT-7B and Hunyuan-MT-Chimera-7B for multilingual translation.
Focus on low-resource languages and dialects.
State-of-the-art results in multilingual translation tasks.

title: BEDTime: A Unified Benchmark for Automatically Describing Time Series
summary:
Many recent studies have proposed general-purpose foundation models designed
for a variety of time series analysis tasks. While several established datasets
already exist for evaluating these models, previous works frequently introduce
their models in conjunction with new datasets, limiting opportunities for
direct, independent comparisons and obscuring insights into the relative
strengths of different methods. Additionally, prior evaluations often cover
numerous tasks simultaneously, assessing a broad range of model abilities
without clearly pinpointing which capabilities contribute to overall
performance. To address these gaps, we formalize and evaluate 3 tasks that test
a model's ability to describe time series using generic natural language: (1)
recognition (True/False question-answering), (2) differentiation (multiple
choice question-answering), and (3) generation (open-ended natural language
description). We then unify 4 recent datasets to enable head-to-head model
comparisons on each task. Experimentally, in evaluating 13 state-of-the-art
language, vision--language, and time series--language models, we find that (1)
popular language-only methods largely underperform, indicating a need for time
series-specific architectures, (2) VLMs are quite successful, as expected,
identifying the value of vision models for these tasks and (3) pretrained
multimodal time series--language models successfully outperform LLMs, but still
have significant room for improvement. We also find that all approaches exhibit
clear fragility in a range of robustness tests. Overall, our benchmark provides
a standardized evaluation on a task necessary for time series reasoning
systems.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates various foundation models for time series analysis by formalizing three specific tasks: recognition, differentiation, and generation, utilizing unified datasets for thorough comparison.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the lack of standardized evaluations and independent comparisons among foundation models used for time series analysis.
AI.method: The authors formalize three specific tasks to assess model capabilities: recognition, differentiation, and generation. They unify four recent datasets to facilitate direct comparisons among 13 state-of-the-art models.
AI.result: The evaluation reveals that popular language-only models underperform, while vision-language models are successful; pretrained multimodal time series-language models outperform LLMs, though improvements are needed.
AI.conclusion: The proposed benchmark offers a systematic evaluation framework for time series reasoning systems, highlighting the need for specialized architectures and better robustness in models.
key_contributions: Formulation of three distinct evaluation tasks for time series analysis
Unification of multiple datasets for comparative model evaluation
Demonstration of performance differences among language-only, vision-language, and multimodal models
AI.limitations: Models exhibit fragility in robustness tests, indicating areas for further research and improvement.

title: HoPE: Hyperbolic Rotary Positional Encoding for Stable Long-Range Dependency Modeling in Large Language Models
comment:
This paper proposes Hyperbolic Rotary Positional Encoding (HoPE), a
  geometric reformulation of positional encoding inspired by Lorentz
  transformations. HoPE addresses limitations of existing methods like RoPE by
  enabling stable long-distance dependency modeling. Code and data will be made
  available upon publication
summary:
Positional encoding mechanisms enable Transformers to model sequential
structure and long-range dependencies in text. While absolute positional
encodings struggle with extrapolation to longer sequences due to fixed
positional representations, and relative approaches like Alibi exhibit
performance degradation on extremely long contexts, the widely-used Rotary
Positional Encoding (RoPE) introduces oscillatory attention patterns that
hinder stable long-distance dependency modelling. We address these limitations
through a geometric reformulation of positional encoding. Drawing inspiration
from Lorentz transformations in hyperbolic geometry, we propose Hyperbolic
Rotary Positional Encoding (HoPE), which leverages hyperbolic functions to
implement Lorentz rotations on token representations. Theoretical analysis
demonstrates that RoPE is a special case of our generalized formulation. HoPE
fundamentally resolves RoPE's slation issues by enforcing monotonic decay of
attention weights with increasing token distances. Extensive experimental
results, including perplexity evaluations under several extended sequence
benchmarks, show that HoPE consistently exceeds existing positional encoding
methods. These findings underscore HoPE's enhanced capacity for representing
and generalizing long-range dependencies. Data and code will be available.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Hyperbolic Rotary Positional Encoding (HoPE), which improves long-distance dependency modeling in Transformers.
AI.motivation: Existing positional encoding methods like RoPE have limitations in modeling long-range dependencies due to oscillatory attention patterns and fixed representations.
AI.method: The paper proposes a geometric reformulation using hyperbolic functions and Lorentz transformations to create HoPE.
AI.result: Experimental results show that HoPE consistently outperforms existing positional encoding methods in repeated sequence benchmarks and supports stable attention weight decay.
AI.conclusion: HoPE offers a better framework for representing and generalizing long-range dependencies in Transformer models compared to its predecessors.
key_contributions: Introduction of Hyperbolic Rotary Positional Encoding (HoPE) for improved long-distance modeling
Generalized formulation that encompasses existing methods like RoPE
Demonstration of consistent performance improvements over standard benchmarks.

title: Less is More Tokens: Efficient Math Reasoning via Difficulty-Aware Chain-of-Thought Distillation
summary:
Chain-of-thought reasoning, while powerful, can produce unnecessarily verbose
output for simpler problems. We present a framework for difficulty-aware
reasoning that teaches models to dynamically adjust reasoning depth based on
problem complexity. Remarkably, we show that models can be endowed with such
dynamic inference pathways without any architectural modifications; we simply
post-train on data that is carefully curated to include chain-of-thought traces
that are proportional in length to problem difficulty. Our analysis reveals
that post-training via supervised fine-tuning (SFT) primarily captures patterns
like reasoning length and format, while direct preference optimization (DPO)
preserves reasoning accuracy, with their combination reducing length and
maintaining or improving performance. Both quantitative metrics and qualitative
assessments confirm that models can learn to "think proportionally", reasoning
minimally on simple problems while maintaining depth for complex ones.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a framework for difficulty-aware reasoning in models, enabling them to adapt their reasoning depth according to problem complexity without changing their architecture.
AI.motivation: Existing chain-of-thought reasoning can lead to verbose outputs for simpler problems, necessitating a more adaptable reasoning approach.
AI.method: The authors propose a post-training method that uses curated data to include reasoning traces proportional to problem difficulty, combining supervised fine-tuning and direct preference optimization to enhance reasoning efficiency.
AI.result: Through their approach, models learn to adjust reasoning depth dynamically, resulting in less verbose answers for simple problems while enhancing performance on complex ones.
AI.conclusion: The study concludes that effective post-training enables models to provide appropriate reasoning depth based on the complexity of problems, thus improving both efficiency and accuracy.
key_contributions: Introduced difficulty-aware reasoning framework for models.
Demonstrated that post-training can achieve dynamic inference without architectural changes.
Combined supervised fine-tuning with direct preference optimization to improve reasoning efficiency.
AI.limitations: Further exploration is needed to generalize findings across diverse problem types and to optimize for even more nuanced reasoning adaptations.

title: CURE: Controlled Unlearning for Robust Embeddings -- Mitigating Conceptual Shortcuts in Pre-Trained Language Models
comment:
Accepted at the Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language
  Processing (EMNLP 2025)
summary:
Pre-trained language models have achieved remarkable success across diverse
applications but remain susceptible to spurious, concept-driven correlations
that impair robustness and fairness. In this work, we introduce CURE, a novel
and lightweight framework that systematically disentangles and suppresses
conceptual shortcuts while preserving essential content information. Our method
first extracts concept-irrelevant representations via a dedicated content
extractor reinforced by a reversal network, ensuring minimal loss of
task-relevant information. A subsequent controllable debiasing module employs
contrastive learning to finely adjust the influence of residual conceptual
cues, enabling the model to either diminish harmful biases or harness
beneficial correlations as appropriate for the target task. Evaluated on the
IMDB and Yelp datasets using three pre-trained architectures, CURE achieves an
absolute improvement of +10 points in F1 score on IMDB and +2 points on Yelp,
while introducing minimal computational overhead. Our approach establishes a
flexible, unsupervised blueprint for combating conceptual biases, paving the
way for more reliable and fair language understanding systems.

AI.tldr: CURE is a framework that reduces conceptual biases in language models while preserving essential information, leading to improved F1 scores on IMDB and Yelp datasets.
AI.motivation: To address the susceptibility of pre-trained language models to spurious correlations that affect robustness and fairness.
AI.method: CURE comprises a content extractor to obtain concept-irrelevant representations and a controllable debiasing module utilizing contrastive learning to adjust biases.
AI.result: CURE improved the F1 score by +10 points on IMDB and +2 points on Yelp, with minimal computational overhead.
AI.conclusion: CURE offers a flexible and unsupervised approach for reducing conceptual biases in language models, contributing to more reliable language understanding.
key_contributions: Introduction of CURE framework for bias reduction
Utilization of a reversal network for content extraction
Implementation of controllable debiasing via contrastive learning

title: Uniform Information Density and Syntactic Reduction: Revisiting $\textit{that}$-Mentioning in English Complement Clauses
summary:
Speakers often have multiple ways to express the same meaning. The Uniform
Information Density (UID) hypothesis suggests that speakers exploit this
variability to maintain a consistent rate of information transmission during
language production. Building on prior work linking UID to syntactic reduction,
we revisit the finding that the optional complementizer $\textit{that}$in
English complement clauses is more likely to be omitted when the clause has low
information density (i.e., more predictable). We advance this line of research
by analyzing a large-scale, contemporary conversational corpus and using
machine learning and neural language models to refine estimates of information
density. Our results replicated the established relationship between
information density and $\textit{that}$-mentioning. However, we found that
previous measures of information density based on matrix verbs'
subcategorization probability capture substantial idiosyncratic lexical
variation. By contrast, estimates derived from contextual word embeddings
account for additional variance in patterns of complementizer usage.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates how speakers manage information transmission during language production, specifically focusing on the use of the complementizer 'that'.
AI.motivation: To explore how variability in language expression can be linked to the Uniform Information Density hypothesis, particularly in terms of the omission of the complementizer 'that'.
AI.method: Analysis of a contemporary conversational corpus utilizing machine learning and neural language models to refine estimates of information density.
AI.result: Confirmed the link between information density and the usage of 'that', revealing that contextual word embeddings provide better insights than previous measures based solely on subcategorization probability.
AI.conclusion: Contextual word embeddings enhance understanding of complementizer usage and its relationship with information density, indicating substantial lexical variation in previous measures.
key_contributions: Introduced machine learning techniques to analyze language production.
Demonstrated the superiority of contextual word embeddings over traditional measures.
Replicated and expanded upon the UID hypothesis regarding the use of 'that' in language.
AI.limitations: Focuses only on conversational English and may not generalize to other languages or dialects.

title: Elucidating the Design Space of Decay in Linear Attention
comment:
Accepted to COLM 2025. Yiran Zhong is the corresponding author. Code
  is available at https://github.com/Doraemonzzz/xmixers
summary:
This paper presents a comprehensive investigation into the decay mechanisms
inherent in linear complexity sequence models. We systematically delineate the
design space of decay mechanisms across four pivotal dimensions:
parameterization strategy, which refers to the computational methodology for
decay; parameter sharing, which involves the utilization of supplementary
parameters for decay computation; decay granularity, comparing scalar versus
vector-based decay; and compatibility with relative positional encoding
methods, such as Rotary Position Embedding (RoPE). Through an extensive series
of experiments conducted on diverse language modeling tasks, we uncovered
several critical insights. Firstly, the design of the parameterization strategy
for decay requires meticulous consideration. Our findings indicate that
effective configurations are typically confined to a specific range of
parameters. Secondly, parameter sharing cannot be used arbitrarily, as it may
cause decay values to be too large or too small, thereby significantly
impacting performance. Thirdly, under identical parameterization strategies,
scalar decay generally underperforms compared to its vector-based counterpart.
However, in certain scenarios with alternative parameterization strategies,
scalar decay may unexpectedly surpass vector decay in efficacy. Lastly, our
analysis reveals that RoPE, a commonly employed relative positional encoding
method, typically fails to provide tangible benefits to the majority of linear
attention mechanisms.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes decay mechanisms in linear complexity sequence models, focusing on parameterization strategies, parameter sharing, decay granularity, and their relation to positional encoding methods.
AI.motivation: To investigate and improve the performance of linear complexity sequence models by examining their decay mechanisms.
AI.method: The authors delineate the design space of decay mechanisms and conduct experiments on various language modeling tasks to evaluate performance outcomes.
AI.result: The study finds specific configurations for decay parameterization are crucial, highlights issues with arbitrary parameter sharing, and compares the performance of scalar versus vector-based decay strategies, revealing unexpected results in certain contexts.
AI.conclusion: Effective decay mechanisms require careful parameterization. Vector decay generally outperforms scalar decay, but specific parameter setups can lead to scalar decay performing surprisingly well, especially with respect to positional encoding methods.
key_contributions: Systematic investigation of decay mechanisms in linear sequence models
Identification of crucial parameterization strategies
Critical evaluation of parameter sharing effects on performance

title: Crosscoding Through Time: Tracking Emergence & Consolidation Of Linguistic Representations Throughout LLM Pretraining
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) learn non-trivial abstractions during
pretraining, like detecting irregular plural noun subjects. However, it is not
well understood when and how specific linguistic abilities emerge as
traditional evaluation methods such as benchmarking fail to reveal how models
acquire concepts and capabilities. To bridge this gap and better understand
model training at the concept level, we use sparse crosscoders to discover and
align features across model checkpoints. Using this approach, we track the
evolution of linguistic features during pretraining. We train crosscoders
between open-sourced checkpoint triplets with significant performance and
representation shifts, and introduce a novel metric, Relative Indirect Effects
(RelIE), to trace training stages at which individual features become causally
important for task performance. We show that crosscoders can detect feature
emergence, maintenance, and discontinuation during pretraining. Our approach is
architecture-agnostic and scalable, offering a promising path toward more
interpretable and fine-grained analysis of representation learning throughout
pretraining.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how linguistic abilities emerge during the pretraining of large language models (LLMs) using sparse crosscoders to analyze model checkpoints.
AI.motivation: To understand when and how linguistic abilities develop in LLMs, as traditional evaluation methods do not adequately capture this process.
AI.method: The authors employ sparse crosscoders to discover and align features across model checkpoints and introduce a novel metric, Relative Indirect Effects (RelIE), to assess feature importance during training stages.
AI.result: The study demonstrates that crosscoders can recognize the emergence, maintenance, and discontinuation of linguistic features throughout pretraining.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method is architecture-agnostic and scalable, contributing to a more interpretable analysis of representation learning in LLMs.
key_contributions: Introduction of sparse crosscoders for feature analysis across model checkpoints.
Novel metric, Relative Indirect Effects (RelIE), for tracing feature causal importance.
Detailed tracking of linguistic feature evolution during LLM pretraining.

title: Modeling Sequential Sentence Relation to Improve Cross-lingual Dense Retrieval
summary:
Recently multi-lingual pre-trained language models (PLM) such as mBERT and
XLM-R have achieved impressive strides in cross-lingual dense retrieval.
Despite its successes, they are general-purpose PLM while the multilingual PLM
tailored for cross-lingual retrieval is still unexplored. Motivated by an
observation that the sentences in parallel documents are approximately in the
same order, which is universal across languages, we propose to model this
sequential sentence relation to facilitate cross-lingual representation
learning. Specifically, we propose a multilingual PLM called masked sentence
model (MSM), which consists of a sentence encoder to generate the sentence
representations, and a document encoder applied to a sequence of sentence
vectors from a document. The document encoder is shared for all languages to
model the universal sequential sentence relation across languages. To train the
model, we propose a masked sentence prediction task, which masks and predicts
the sentence vector via a hierarchical contrastive loss with sampled negatives.
Comprehensive experiments on four cross-lingual retrieval tasks show MSM
significantly outperforms existing advanced pre-training models, demonstrating
the effectiveness and stronger cross-lingual retrieval capabilities of our
approach. Code and model are available at https://github.com/shunyuzh/MSM.

AI.tldr: Proposes a multilingual pre-trained language model (MSM) that improves cross-lingual retrieval by modeling sequential sentence relations.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of multilingual PLMs tailored for cross-lingual retrieval, leveraging the universal alignment of sentences in parallel documents.
AI.method: Introduces a masked sentence model (MSM) with a sentence encoder and a shared document encoder for all languages, using a masked sentence prediction task combined with hierarchical contrastive loss for training.
AI.result: MSM achieves significant improvements over existing pre-training models in cross-lingual retrieval across four tasks.
AI.conclusion: The proposed MSM model demonstrates stronger retrieval capabilities and is more effective than current state-of-the-art multilingual PLMs.
key_contributions: Introduction of a tailored multilingual PLM for cross-lingual retrieval.
Development of a masked sentence prediction task for training.
Demonstration of superior retrieval performance compared to existing models.

title: Demystifying Chains, Trees, and Graphs of Thoughts
summary:
The field of natural language processing (NLP) has witnessed significant
progress in recent years, with a notable focus on improving large language
models' (LLM) performance through innovative prompting techniques. Among these,
prompt engineering coupled with structures has emerged as a promising paradigm,
with designs such as Chain-of-Thought, Tree of Thoughts, or Graph of Thoughts,
in which the overall LLM reasoning is guided by a structure such as a graph. As
illustrated with numerous examples, this paradigm significantly enhances the
LLM's capability to solve numerous tasks, ranging from logical or mathematical
reasoning to planning or creative writing. To facilitate the understanding of
this growing field and pave the way for future developments, we devise a
general blueprint for effective and efficient LLM reasoning schemes. For this,
we conduct an in-depth analysis of the prompt execution pipeline, clarifying
and clearly defining different concepts. We then build the first taxonomy of
structure-enhanced LLM reasoning schemes. We focus on identifying fundamental
classes of harnessed structures, and we analyze the representations of these
structures, algorithms executed with these structures, and many others. We
refer to these structures as reasoning topologies, because their representation
becomes to a degree spatial, as they are contained within the LLM context. Our
study compares existing prompting schemes using the proposed taxonomy,
discussing how certain design choices lead to different patterns in performance
and cost. We also outline theoretical underpinnings, relationships between
prompting and other parts of the LLM ecosystem such as knowledge bases, and the
associated research challenges. Our work will help to advance future prompt
engineering techniques.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of structure-enhanced prompting techniques for large language models (LLMs), introducing a taxonomy for effective reasoning schemes.
AI.motivation: To enhance the performance of LLMs through structured prompting techniques and facilitate future developments in the field of NLP.
AI.method: An in-depth analysis of the prompt execution pipeline, defining concepts, and creating a taxonomy of structure-enhanced reasoning schemes for LLMs.
AI.result: The proposed taxonomy identifies fundamental classes of structures and analyzes their representations, leading to insights on performance and cost of different prompting strategies.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a foundational framework for advancing prompt engineering techniques, showing relationships between prompting, LLMs, and knowledge bases.
key_contributions: First taxonomy of structure-enhanced LLM reasoning schemes
In-depth analysis of prompt execution pipeline
Comparison of prompting schemes and their performance patterns

title: AnyGPT: Unified Multimodal LLM with Discrete Sequence Modeling
comment: 28 pages, 16 figures, under review, work in progress
summary:
We introduce AnyGPT, an any-to-any multimodal language model that utilizes
discrete representations for the unified processing of various modalities,
including speech, text, images, and music. AnyGPT can be trained stably without
any alterations to the current large language model (LLM) architecture or
training paradigms. Instead, it relies exclusively on data-level preprocessing,
facilitating the seamless integration of new modalities into LLMs, akin to the
incorporation of new languages. We build a multimodal text-centric dataset for
multimodal alignment pre-training. Utilizing generative models, we synthesize
the first large-scale any-to-any multimodal instruction dataset. It consists of
108k samples of multi-turn conversations that intricately interweave various
modalities, thus equipping the model to handle arbitrary combinations of
multimodal inputs and outputs. Experimental results demonstrate that AnyGPT is
capable of facilitating any-to-any multimodal conversation while achieving
performance comparable to specialized models across all modalities, proving
that discrete representations can effectively and conveniently unify multiple
modalities within a language model. Demos are shown in
https://junzhan2000.github.io/AnyGPT.github.io/

AI.tldr: AnyGPT is a multimodal language model that processes speech, text, images, and music using discrete representations for unified any-to-any interaction.
AI.motivation: The need for an efficient multimodal processing model that integrates various modalities into large language models without requiring architectural changes.
AI.method: AnyGPT employs data-level preprocessing to facilitate the integration of diverse modalities. A multimodal text-centric dataset is created for pre-training, consisting of 108k samples that enable the model to handle complex multimodal conversations.
AI.result: AnyGPT achieves performance comparable to specialized models across modalities, enabling effective any-to-any multimodal conversations.
AI.conclusion: The model demonstrates that discrete representations can unify multiple modalities efficiently within a language model framework.
key_contributions: Introduction of a novel any-to-any multimodal language model
Creation of a large-scale multimodal instruction dataset
Demonstration of performance parity with specialized models

title: ATHAR: A High-Quality and Diverse Dataset for Classical Arabic to English Translation
summary:
Classical Arabic represents a significant era that encompasses the golden age
of Arab culture, philosophy, and scientific literature. With a broad consensus
on the importance of translating these literatures to enrich knowledge
dissemination across communities, the advent of large language models (LLMs)
and translation systems offers promising tools to facilitate this goal.
However, we have identified a scarcity of translation datasets in Classical
Arabic, which are often limited in scope and topics, hindering the development
of high-quality translation systems. In response, we present the ATHAR dataset,
which comprises 66,000 high-quality classical Arabic to English translation
samples that cover a wide array of topics including science, culture, and
philosophy. Furthermore, we assess the performance of current state-of-the-art
LLMs under various settings, concluding that there is a need for such datasets
in current systems. Our findings highlight how models can benefit from
fine-tuning or incorporating this dataset into their pretraining pipelines. The
dataset is publicly available on the HuggingFace Data Hub:
https://huggingface.co/datasets/mohamed-khalil/ATHAR.

AI.tldr: The ATHAR dataset provides 66,000 high-quality translations from Classical Arabic to English, addressing the scarcity of such datasets.
AI.motivation: To enrich knowledge dissemination by providing high-quality translation resources for Classical Arabic literature.
AI.method: Creation of a dataset comprising 66,000 classical Arabic to English translation samples across various topics; assessment of state-of-the-art LLMs using this dataset.
AI.result: Current LLMs show improved performance when fine-tuned or integrated with the ATHAR dataset.
AI.conclusion: The availability of the ATHAR dataset is essential for advancing translation systems for Classical Arabic, highlighting a need for further development in this area.
key_contributions: Introduction of the ATHAR dataset with 66,000 translation samples
Diverse coverage of topics including science, culture, and philosophy
Assessment of LLM performance using the dataset, highlighting the need for such resources.

title: Selective Preference Optimization via Token-Level Reward Function Estimation
comment: Accepted by the EMNLP 2025 main conference
summary:
Recent advancements in large language model alignment leverage token-level
supervisions to perform fine-grained preference optimization. However, existing
token-level alignment methods either optimize on all available tokens, which
can be noisy and inefficient, or perform selective training with complex and
expensive key token selection strategies. In this work, we propose Selective
Preference Optimization (SePO), a novel selective alignment strategy that
centers on efficient key token selection. SePO proposes the first token
selection method based on Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), which trains an
oracle model to estimate a token-level reward function on the target data. This
method applies to any existing alignment datasets with response-level
annotations and enables cost-efficient token selection with small-scale oracle
models and training data. The estimated reward function is then utilized to
score all tokens within the target dataset, where only the key tokens are
selected to supervise the target policy model with a reference model-free
contrastive objective function. Extensive experiments on three public
evaluation benchmarks show that SePO significantly outperforms competitive
baseline methods by only optimizing 30% key tokens on the target dataset. SePO
applications on weak-to-strong generalization show that weak oracle models
effectively supervise strong policy models with up to 16.8x more parameters.
SePO also effectively selects key tokens from out-of-distribution data to
enhance strong policy models and alleviate the over-optimization problem.

AI.tldr: SePO is a selective alignment strategy for optimizing large language models through efficient token selection, outperforming existing methods.
AI.motivation: The need for efficient and less noisy token-level preference optimization in large language model alignment.
AI.method: SePO utilizes Direct Preference Optimization to train a model that selects key tokens for a target policy model, minimizing training cost through efficient token selection.
AI.result: Demonstrated significant improvements in performance by optimizing only 30% of the key tokens across multiple benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: SePO facilitates better training efficiency and mitigates over-optimization, particularly in environments with limited data.
key_contributions: Introduction of Selective Preference Optimization (SePO) for token selection.
Use of Direct Preference Optimization for training token selection models.
Demonstrated effectiveness of weak oracle models in supervising larger policy models.

title: LogicPro: Improving Complex Logical Reasoning via Program-Guided Learning
summary:
In this paper, we propose a new data synthesis method called
\textbf{LogicPro}, which leverages LeetCode-style algorithm
\underline{Pro}blems and their corresponding \underline{Pro}gram solutions to
synthesize Complex \underline{Logic}al Reasoning data in text format. First, we
synthesize complex reasoning problems through source algorithm problems and
test cases. Then, standard answers and intermediate variable outputs are
obtained for each problem based on standard python solutions and test cases.
Finally, with the guidance of code intermediate variables, we synthesize the
text reasoning process for each reasoning problems. Through this method, we can
synthesize data that is difficult, scalable, effective, and comes with golden
standard answers and high-quality reasoning processes. As a result, with our
540K synthesized dataset constructed solely from 2,360 algorithm problems, our
approach \footnote{Code and data are publicly available at
https://github.com/jiangjin1999/LogicPro} achieves significant improvements in
multiple models for the datasets \textit{BBH$^{27}$}, \textit{LogicBench},
\textit{DROP}, \textit{AR-LSAT}, and \textit{GSM8K}, etc. outperforming a wide
range of existing reasoning datasets.

AI.tldr: This paper presents LogicPro, a data synthesis method that creates high-quality logical reasoning data using algorithm problems from LeetCode and Python solutions.
AI.motivation: The goal is to synthesize complex logical reasoning data that is difficult and scalable with high-quality outputs.
AI.method: LogicPro synthesizes reasoning problems from algorithm problems and test cases, outputs standard answers, and creates a comprehensive reasoning text process for each problem.
AI.result: The method resulted in a dataset of 540K synthesized reasoning problems from 2,360 algorithm problems, improving performance on several existing reasoning datasets.
AI.conclusion: LogicPro provides an effective approach for data synthesis in logical reasoning, outperforming existing datasets.
key_contributions: Introduction of LogicPro for logical reasoning data synthesis
Creation of a 540K dataset from algorithm problems with high-quality outputs
Significant performance improvements on multiple reasoning benchmarks

title: What fifty-one years of Linguistics and Artificial Intelligence research tell us about their correlation: A scientometric analysis
summary:
There is a strong correlation between linguistics and artificial intelligence
(AI), best manifested by deep learning language models. This study provides a
thorough scientometric analysis of this correlation, synthesizing the
intellectual production over 51 years, from 1974 to 2024. Web of Science Core
Collection (WoSCC) database was the data source. The data collected were
analyzed by two powerful software, viz., CiteSpace and VOSviewer, through which
mapping visualizations of the intellectual landscape, trending issues and
(re)emerging hotspots were generated. The results indicate that in the 1980s
and 1990s, linguistics and AI (AIL) research was not robust, characterized by
unstable publication over time. It has, however, witnessed a remarkable
increase of publication since then, reaching 1478 articles in 2023, and 546
articles in January-March timespan in 2024, involving emerging issues including
Natural language processing, Cross-sectional study, Using bidirectional encoder
representation, and Using ChatGPT and hotspots such as Novice programmer,
Prioritization, and Artificial intelligence, addressing new horizons, new
topics, and launching new applications and powerful deep learning language
models including ChatGPT. It concludes that linguistics and AI correlation is
established at several levels, research centers, journals, and countries
shaping AIL knowledge production and reshaping its future frontiers.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the correlation between linguistics and AI through a scientometric analysis spanning 51 years, highlighting significant increases in publications and emerging trends in language models like ChatGPT.
AI.motivation: To explore the strong correlation between linguistics and AI, evidenced by the growth of research and publications over several decades.
AI.method: A scientometric analysis using the Web of Science Core Collection database, with data visualizations generated by CiteSpace and VOSviewer.
AI.result: The analysis revealed an increase in publications from the 1980s to 2023, with 1478 articles published in 2023 alone, and identification of emerging themes in NLP and AI.
AI.conclusion: The correlation between linguistics and AI is well-established across research centers, journals, and countries, influencing the production of knowledge in artificial intelligence linguistics.
key_contributions: Analysis of 51 years of linguistic and AI research
Identification of key trends and hotspots in publications
Visual representations of the intellectual landscape in AIL research

title: Assessing the Sensitivity and Alignment of FOL Closeness Metrics
summary:
The recent successful paradigm of solving logical reasoning problems with
tool-augmented large language models (LLMs) leverages translation of natural
language (NL) statements into First-Order Logic~(FOL) and external theorem
provers. However, the correctness of FOL statements, comprising operators and
text, often go unverified due to the lack of a reliable evaluation metric for
comparing generated and ground-truth FOLs. In this paper, we conduct a
comprehensive study on the sensitivity of existing NL-, FOL-, and graph-based
metrics to capture differences between a sampled FOL and its corresponding
ground-truth. We then measure the alignment between a metric-based ranking of
FOL outputs and a strong LLM as-a-judge. To do this, we first apply operator
and text-based perturbations to ground-truth FOL statements to assess metric
sensitivity. We then evaluate metric robustness by comparing the metrics
against LLMs judgment. Our empirical findings highlight a clear oversensitivity
in the n-gram metric BLEU for text perturbations. The operator perturbation
affects the semantic graph metric Smatch++ for structural changes, and the FOL
metric for specific operator changes. We observe a closer alignment between
BertScore and LLM judgement, proving the importance of semantic evaluation.
Additionally, we show that combining metrics enhances both robustness and
sensitivity compared to using individual metrics.

AI.tldr: This paper examines the sensitivity of existing evaluation metrics for comparing generated First-Order Logic (FOL) statements with ground-truth data, particularly in the context of tool-augmented large language models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: The correctness of FOL statements in logical reasoning problems using LLMs is often unverified due to unreliable evaluation metrics, highlighting a need for better measurement tools.
AI.method: The study assesses the sensitivity of existing NL, FOL, and graph-based metrics by applying perturbations to FOL statements and evaluating their alignment with judgments made by a strong LLM.
AI.result: The findings reveal that the n-gram metric BLEU is oversensitive to text perturbations, while BertScore aligns more closely with LLM judgments. Combining multiple metrics shows improved robustness and sensitivity.
AI.conclusion: The paper emphasizes the need for improved semantic evaluation metrics in the context of LLMs and suggests that a combination of metrics may provide a better evaluation framework.
key_contributions: In-depth analysis of the sensitivity of various metrics for evaluating FOL statements.
Demonstration of the oversensitivity of the BLEU metric for text perturbations.
Introduction of the improvement in evaluation robustness through the combination of multiple metrics.
AI.limitations: The study primarily focuses on certain metrics and may not cover all potential evaluation tools available for FOL statements.

title: Large Language Models with Temporal Reasoning for Longitudinal Clinical Summarization and Prediction
summary:
Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have shown potential in
clinical text summarization, but their ability to handle long patient
trajectories with multi-modal data spread across time remains underexplored.
This study systematically evaluates several state-of-the-art open-source LLMs,
their Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) variants and chain-of-thought (CoT)
prompting on long-context clinical summarization and prediction. We examine
their ability to synthesize structured and unstructured Electronic Health
Records (EHR) data while reasoning over temporal coherence, by re-engineering
existing tasks, including discharge summarization and diagnosis prediction from
two publicly available EHR datasets. Our results indicate that long context
windows improve input integration but do not consistently enhance clinical
reasoning, and LLMs are still struggling with temporal progression and rare
disease prediction. While RAG shows improvements in hallucination in some
cases, it does not fully address these limitations. Our work fills the gap in
long clinical text summarization, establishing a foundation for evaluating LLMs
with multi-modal data and temporal reasoning.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates state-of-the-art LLMs for summarizing long clinical texts with multi-modal EHR data, revealing both improvements and persistent challenges in temporal reasoning.
AI.motivation: To explore the capabilities of LLMs in handling extensive, multi-modal clinical data and the challenges in clinical reasoning and prediction due to temporal factors.
AI.method: The study evaluates various open-source LLMs, RAG variants, and chain-of-thought prompting techniques using two EHR datasets for tasks like discharge summarization and diagnosis prediction.
AI.result: Long context windows enhance the integration of input data, but do not universally improve clinical reasoning; LLMs struggle with temporal coherence and rare disease predictions.
AI.conclusion: This work provides a foundation for assessing LLMs in the context of long clinical text summarization, addressing both successes and limitations in multi-modal and temporal reasoning.
key_contributions: Systematic evaluation of state-of-the-art LLMs in clinical summarization
Insights into the effectiveness of multi-modal data integration
Identification of limitations in temporal reasoning and rare disease prediction
AI.limitations: LLMs still face challenges in maintaining temporal coherence and accurately predicting rare diseases despite improvements with long context and RAG.

title: StereoDetect: Detecting Stereotypes and Anti-stereotypes the Correct Way Using Social Psychological Underpinnings
summary:
Stereotypes are known to have very harmful effects, making their detection
critically important. However, current research predominantly focuses on
detecting and evaluating stereotypical biases, thereby leaving the study of
stereotypes in its early stages. Our study revealed that many works have failed
to clearly distinguish between stereotypes and stereotypical biases, which has
significantly slowed progress in advancing research in this area. Stereotype
and Anti-stereotype detection is a problem that requires social knowledge;
hence, it is one of the most difficult areas in Responsible AI. This work
investigates this task, where we propose a five-tuple definition and provide
precise terminologies disentangling stereotypes, anti-stereotypes,
stereotypical bias, and general bias. We provide a conceptual framework
grounded in social psychology for reliable detection. We identify key
shortcomings in existing benchmarks for this task of stereotype and
anti-stereotype detection. To address these gaps, we developed StereoDetect, a
well curated, definition-aligned benchmark dataset designed for this task. We
show that sub-10B language models and GPT-4o frequently misclassify
anti-stereotypes and fail to recognize neutral overgeneralizations. We
demonstrate StereoDetect's effectiveness through multiple qualitative and
quantitative comparisons with existing benchmarks and models fine-tuned on
them. The dataset and code is available at
https://github.com/KaustubhShejole/StereoDetect.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the critical task of stereotype and anti-stereotype detection in AI, proposing a new benchmark, StereoDetect, to enhance reliability in detection practices.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of clarity in distinguishing between stereotypes and stereotypical biases, leading to stagnation in research progress in stereotype detection.
AI.method: The authors propose a five-tuple definition and provide a conceptual framework grounded in social psychology, along with developing a benchmark dataset, StereoDetect, for effective stereotype detection.
AI.result: The study reveals that existing language models, including sub-10B models and GPT-4o, frequently misclassify anti-stereotypes and struggle with neutral overgeneralizations, showcasing the limitations of current benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: StereoDetect is an effective tool for improving stereotype detection in AI, addressing key gaps in the existing research landscape.
key_contributions: Introduction of a five-tuple definition for stereotypes and biased concepts
Development of the StereoDetect benchmark dataset
Identification of shortcomings in existing stereotype detection benchmarks

title: Can LLMs Simulate Personas with Reversed Performance? A Benchmark for Counterfactual Instruction Following
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are now increasingly widely used to simulate
personas in virtual environments, leveraging their instruction-following
capability. However, we discovered that even state-of-the-art LLMs cannot
simulate personas with reversed performance (e.g., student personas with low
proficiency in educational settings), which impairs the simulation diversity
and limits the practical applications of the simulated environments. In this
work, using mathematical reasoning as a representative scenario, we propose the
first benchmark dataset for evaluating LLMs on simulating personas with
reversed performance, a capability that we dub "counterfactual instruction
following". We evaluate both open-weight and closed-source LLMs on this task
and find that LLMs, including the OpenAI o1 reasoning model, all struggle to
follow counterfactual instructions for simulating reversedly performing
personas. Intersectionally simulating both the performance level and the race
population of a persona worsens the effect even further. These results
highlight the challenges of counterfactual instruction following and the need
for further research.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a benchmark dataset to evaluate LLMs' ability to simulate personas with reversed performance, revealing their limitations in counterfactual instruction following.
AI.motivation: The motivation behind this work is to enhance the ability of Large Language Models to simulate diverse personas, particularly those that exhibit reversed performance in educational settings, which current models struggle to do.
AI.method: The authors propose a benchmark dataset specifically designed to assess LLMs on their capability to follow counterfactual instructions and simulate personas with reversed performance, focusing on mathematical reasoning as a key example.
AI.result: The evaluation reveals that both open-weight and closed-source LLMs struggle significantly with following counterfactual instructions, particularly when simulating reversed performance personas, and the intersection of performance level and race further complicates the simulation.
AI.conclusion: The findings underscore the limitations of current LLMs in effectively simulating a diverse range of personas and highlight the necessity for additional research in counterfactual instruction following.
key_contributions: Introduction of a benchmark dataset for evaluating counterfactual instruction following in LLMs.
Analysis of LLM performance in simulating reversed personas in educational contexts.
Discussion of the intersectional challenges faced by LLMs when simulating personas.
AI.limitations: The study is limited to evaluating LLMs in the context of mathematical reasoning and may not encompass all areas of counterfactual instruction following.

title: ViClaim: A Multilingual Multilabel Dataset for Automatic Claim Detection in Videos
summary:
The growing influence of video content as a medium for communication and
misinformation underscores the urgent need for effective tools to analyze
claims in multilingual and multi-topic settings. Existing efforts in
misinformation detection largely focus on written text, leaving a significant
gap in addressing the complexity of spoken text in video transcripts. We
introduce ViClaim, a dataset of 1,798 annotated video transcripts across three
languages (English, German, Spanish) and six topics. Each sentence in the
transcripts is labeled with three claim-related categories: fact-check-worthy,
fact-non-check-worthy, or opinion. We developed a custom annotation tool to
facilitate the highly complex annotation process. Experiments with
state-of-the-art multilingual language models demonstrate strong performance in
cross-validation (macro F1 up to 0.896) but reveal challenges in generalization
to unseen topics, particularly for distinct domains. Our findings highlight the
complexity of claim detection in video transcripts. ViClaim offers a robust
foundation for advancing misinformation detection in video-based communication,
addressing a critical gap in multimodal analysis.

AI.tldr: ViClaim is a dataset of 1,798 annotated video transcripts in English, German, and Spanish for analyzing claims to enhance misinformation detection in video content.
AI.motivation: The increasing role of video content for communication and misinformation necessitates effective tools for analyzing claims, particularly in spoken text, which is under-researched.
AI.method: Development of ViClaim, a dataset of annotated video transcripts with a custom annotation tool, alongside experiments using multilingual language models.
AI.result: Strong performance in claim detection with macro F1 scores up to 0.896 in cross-validation, but challenges in generalization for unseen topics.
AI.conclusion: ViClaim serves as a significant resource for improving misinformation detection in video settings, indicating the intricate challenges within multimodal analysis.
key_contributions: Introduction of ViClaim dataset for multilingual video transcripts
Development of a custom tool for complex annotation
Demonstration of state-of-the-art model performance with insights into generalization challenges
AI.limitations: The dataset may struggle with generalization to distinct unseen topics due to its focus on specific domains.

title: First Steps Towards Overhearing LLM Agents: A Case Study With Dungeons & Dragons Gameplay
comment: 9 pages, 5 figures. COLM 2025 Workshop on AI Agents
summary:
Much work has been done on conversational LLM agents which directly assist
human users with tasks. We present an alternative paradigm for interacting with
LLM agents, which we call "overhearing agents". These overhearing agents do not
actively participate in conversation -- instead, they "listen in" on
human-to-human conversations and perform background tasks or provide
suggestions to assist the user. In this work, we explore the overhearing agents
paradigm through the lens of Dungeons & Dragons gameplay. We present an
in-depth study using large multimodal audio-language models as overhearing
agents to assist a Dungeon Master. We perform a human evaluation to examine the
helpfulness of such agents and find that some large audio-language models have
the emergent ability to perform overhearing agent tasks using implicit audio
cues. Finally, we release Python libraries and our project code to support
further research into the overhearing agents paradigm at
https://github.com/zhudotexe/overhearing_agents.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a new interaction paradigm involving LLM agents known as "overhearing agents," which assist users by passively listening to human conversations, showcased through a study in Dungeons & Dragons gameplay.
AI.motivation: To explore alternative methods for LLM interaction that do not require direct user engagement, offering a new dimension to assistive technology.
AI.method: An in-depth study utilizing large multimodal audio-language models as overhearing agents during Dungeons & Dragons gameplay, including a human evaluation to measure effectiveness.
AI.result: The evaluation indicated that some large audio-language models could successfully perform overhearing tasks by interpreting implicit audio cues, demonstrating emergent capabilities.
AI.conclusion: The findings support the potential of overhearing agents in providing subtle assistance while users engage in conversation and offer resources for further research.
key_contributions: Introduction of the overhearing agents paradigm
Demonstration through Dungeons & Dragons gameplay
Release of tools and code for further research
AI.limitations: The study is limited to a specific application (Dungeons & Dragons) and may require further validation in broader contexts.
